metadata.title: Subcutaneous Emphysema, Traumatic
description: Subcutaneous emphysema (SE) is a disorder in which air becomes trapped beneath the skin(16)
It often is due to trauma and injury to lung or air passages, with air moving under the skin(12)
It is most often characterized by a crackling sensation when palpated and an alarming appearance as the face, neck, body, and scrotum become misshapen(12)

Physical and occupational therapists do not treat SE. However, patients with diagnoses that require physical and/or occupational therapy may present with SE as a complication or may develop SE during the rehabilitation course

ICD-10 codes.Traumatic: subcutaneous emphysema, initial encounter T79.7XXA (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Swelling all over body (face, neck, body, scrotum)(2,12)
Positive Hamman’s sign (i.e., “systolic crunching noise” upon auscultation of the heart)(3)
Respiratory distress in patients with cervical SE(3)

Patients with SE typically have comorbid conditions. See the appropriate Clinical Review for specific signs and symptoms Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors SENA A new discovery of symptoms of SE necessitates an immediate referral to an appropriate physician (or hospital) for medical interventionNA NA Patient at risk for SE _ _ Secondary complications (e.g., pneumonia, atelectasis) of SE and comorbidities (e.g., rib fracture, chest tube)Prevent SE _ _ Prevention of secondary complicationsPatient education _ Educate patient on how to avoid the development of SE. See Maintenance or Prevention , below _ _ Early mobilization (as allowed by physician), deep breathing exercises, position changes in bedProgress patient as indicated and appropriateEducate family/ caregivers, bedside breathing exercises ROM, strength, functional, and balance and gait impairments due to comorbid conditions _ _ Decreased endurance, shortness of breath with activityImprove ROM, strength, function, gait, and balance _ _ Improve endurance, decrease SOBFunctional training _ See appropriate Clinical Review for specific comorbidity for more details _ _ Endurance training, dyspnea relief positions, breathing exercisesSee appropriate Clinical Review for more detailsSee appropriate Clinical Review for more details _ _ Provide instructions for home program . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with SE typically have comorbid conditions. See the appropriate Clinical Review for specific contraindications/ precautions

causes ,: Infectious SE–SE can result from bacterial infections (e.g., severe tonsillitis). This type of SE is notdiscussed in this Clinical Review–Trauma can result in infection, which can cause SE(11)

Noninfectious SE–SE can occur following trauma (e.g., car accidents, stabbings), surgery (e.g., joint arthroscopy), or medical procedures(e.g., subcutaneous injections, intubation, colonoscopy)(2,16,18)-A case of massive subcutaneous neck emphysema followed an emergent surgical tracheotomy (that was performed inresponse to a stab injury to the floor of the mouth) and was felt to be because the hemorrhage had not been controlledprior to the tracheotomy(13)-Certain medical procedures that insert a tube into the body, such as endoscopy, a central venous line, endotrachealintubation, and bronchoscopy, increase risk of SE(4)-Fenestrated tracheostomy tubes allow for phonation, which helps patients start speaking sooner. However, patientsreceiving mechanical ventilation may experience complications,including SE. Authors of a systematic review onspeech and safety in tracheostomy patients receiving mechanical ventilation found that the incidence of subcutaneousemphysema is increased when a fenestrated tube is place in a fresh tracheostomy. Optimal positioning is key to avoidthis complication(20)-Authors of a literature review found that SE can occur after transanal procedures(18)-Authors of a systematic review evaluated the efficacy and safety of omitting chest drains after video-assistedthoracoscopic surgery. They found no significant difference in the incidence of SE between the chest drain group and thenochest drain group(19)–Fracture (e.g., facial, rib)–Ruptured bronchial tube(s) or esophagus-A case study was reported of a 28-day-old  neonate in whom stridor and SE were the only signs of physical abuse(14)-Neonate did not have palpable SE but was found to have extensive gas dissecting through the structures in her neck,esophagus, and right mainstem bronchus region by CT scan-Hypopharyngeal perforation was diagnosed that was due to her father giving her a “solid jolt, causing her head to goback and forth forcefully”–Pneumothorax–Dental procedures(17)-Dental procedures involving the mandibular molars are more frequently involved due to their closer relationship withhead and neck spaces. The use of air syringes or air-driven  dental handpieces is a risk factor for development of SE–Insufflation of air during the course of laparoscopy or via the female genital tract during a pelvic examination, especiallyduring pregnancy(16)–Childbirth(16)–Breathing in cocaine(4)–Isolated periorbital emphysema(15)-Dental procedures, facial trauma, and sneezing–Corrosives or chemical burns of the esophagus(4)–Forceful vomiting (Boerhaave's syndrome)(4)–Air can also be found in between skin layers on the arms and legs or torso after scuba diving
pathogenesis: Trauma allows air from the chest cavity, lungs, or GI system to travel under the skin
Air can travel along tissue planes for some distance(12)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with SE typically have comorbid conditions. See the appropriate Clinical Review for specific contraindications/

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with SE typically have comorbid conditions. See the appropriate Clinical Review for specific contraindications/

other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Physical and occupational therapists do not treat patients specifically for SE. Patients with other diagnoses, however, might have SE as a complication
prognosis: Uncomplicated SE typically resolves on its own by spontaneous absorption,(7) if air leak is treated or stops spontaneously(12)
Occasionally, however, SE results in respiratory distress(3,7)
A tracheostomy can be indicated if the trapped air is causing undue pressure on the airway(12)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: If SE is suspected, refer patient back to treating physician

maintenance or prevention: Following surgery or trauma, patient should be instructed to avoid the Valsalva maneuver (e.g., during nose blowing)
